byline.contributor: Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle reported from London, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Salman Masood from Islamabad; Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea; Alissa J. Rubin from Paris; Dionne Searcey from Dakar, Senegal; Neil MacFarquhar and Ivan Nechepurenko from Moscow; Michael Forsythe and Austin Ramzy from Hong Kong; Alison Smale from Berlin; James Kanter from Brussels; Sewell Chan from London; Michael D. Shear from Washington; Simon Romero from Rio de Janeiro; and Pascale Bonnefoy from Santiago, Chile.
byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER, STEPHEN CASTLE and RICK GLADSTONE

abstract: Leak of documents from boutique Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca showing vast wealth hidden by politicians around globe has raised public outcry and demands for resignation of several leaders; documents, known as Panama Papers, demonstrate how wealthy people hide money in secretive shell companies and offshore tax havens.
lead_paragraph: The departure of Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson is the most prominent fallout from the leaked papers. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is also battling revelations that involve his family.

headline.main: Iceland’s Prime Minister Steps Down Amid Panama Papers Scandal
headline.print_headline: Panama Papers Stir Inquiries and Outrage

snippet: The departure of Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson is the most prominent fallout from the leaked papers. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is also battling revelations that involve his family.
